Administration supports lesbian employee's case
 By SUDHIN THANAWALA, Associated Press - 4 days ago
 SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - In a strongly worded legal brief, the Obama administration has said the federal act that defines marriage as being between a man and a woman was motivated by hostility toward gays and lesbians and is unconstitutional.
 The brief was filed Friday in federal court in San Francisco in support of a lesbian federal employee's lawsuit claiming the government wrongly denied health insurance coverage to her same-sex spouse.
 The Justice Department says Karen Golinski's suit should not be dismissed because the law under which her spouse was denied benefits - the Defense of Marriage Act - violates the U.S. Constitution's guarantee of equal protection.
 "The official legislative record makes plain that DOMA Section 3 was motivated in large part by animus toward gay and lesbian individuals and their intimate relationships, and Congress identified no other interest that is materially advanced by Section 3," the brief reads, referring to the section in the act that defines marriage as being between a man and a woman.
 Though the administration has previously said it will not defend the marriage act, the brief is the first court filing in which it urges the court to find the law unconstitutional, said Tobias Barrington Wolff, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
 "This brief represents the concrete manifestation of a complete paradigm shift in the federal government's position on anti-gay discrimination and the constitutional rights of married same-sex couples," Wolff said in a phone interview Saturday.
 The brief argues that gays and lesbians have been subject to a history of discrimination by federal, state and local governments and private parties. It also lays out the administration's position that sexual orientation is an "immutable characteristic," that gays and lesbians are minorities with limited political power and that sexual orientation has no bearing on someone's ability to contribute to society and advances no legitimate policy interest.
 "It's quite powerful to have the administration saying in a court filing that this kind of discrimination should be viewed suspiciously," said Tara Borelli, an attorney for Golinski.
 Attorneys for a U.S. House of Representatives group that has stepped in to defend the marriage act's constitutionality in the Golinski case did not immediately respond to requests for comment. House Republicans previously had criticized Obama administration's decision that the marriage act was unconstitutional and would not be defended by the Department of Justice in court.
 In court filings, they have said that multiple courts have relied on Congress's justifications for enacting the law to uphold its constitutionality.
 Golinski is a 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals lawyer. She sued the U.S. Office of Personnel Management last year for not authorizing family health insurance coverage for her same-sex spouse.
 Her attorneys are now seeking summary judgment in her favor.

 I'm saying that the Bible helps us to work out what is sinful, but that ultimately God decides. It's not a matter of ignoring it "if you feel like", but some commands in the Bible need to be examined in context, specifically the context of what Christ commanded. The wearing of mixed fibre clothing, touching a woman who is having a period, and many other things were considered sinful according to the law of Moses. Does it conflict with loving God? Does it conflict with loving your neighbour as yourself? At the time Paul was writing (and it is Paul, Jesus said nothing on homosexuality, unlike divorce and adultery), when pretty much everyone married, unless they had taken a vow of celibacy, anyone engaging in homosexual activity was betraying their spouse or their promise to God; worse still, most of the open homosexuality Paul would have known about would have been in the context of pagan religious practices. Historical context is vital. Every other command still observed (including those on adultery and fornication, and divorce) is consistent with the 2 great commandments that Jesus highlighted. For some gay people, they may have put their sexuality before their relationship with God, but some straight people are guilty of doing that too.
 
 God's laws have a purpose, Jesus did not command certain behaviour for the sake of it. Every thing that Christ spoke against in the Gospel was and is demonstrably damaging to our love for God or for our neighbours. If I want to be certain of whether something is sinful, it is Christ's standard I will measure it against, not the jots and tattles of obscure passages in the epistles or mosaic law. I am fortunate in that the issue of homosexuality is not one that is personal to me, but I think there is enough doubt, as with usury (and certainly more so than divorce) or contraception, for the decision to be between individuals and God as to whether certain behaviour is acceptable.
 
 As for the 10 commandments, I think they are threaded through a lot of the Bible, but some more so than others. "Honour thy father and thy mother" is somewhat contradicted by Christ drawing attention to the conflict he will bring to families. The commandment doesn't now mean perhaps what it was thought to mean when first written. The theme of idolatry is returned to repeatedly, how it draws attention from God to the creations of our own hearts and hands. Blasphemy is less explicitly alluded to, but taking the Lord's name in vain necessarily goes against the first of the great commandments (which obviously also covers the first of the ten). Adultery is returned to, as is covetousness and greed, and dishonesty. Theft is not touched on much, but on most cases that will contradict loving your neighbour. Keeping a day apart to honour God is in accordance with the first commandment, though Jesus made clear that if others need help or you need food then it is ok to do that on the sabbath, because the sabbath is as much a day for people as it is for God. And killing is pretty much a no-no by any interpretation.
